ci_support_linux_64_.yaml:
cdt_name:
- conda
channel_sources:
- conda-forge
channel_targets:
- conda-forge main
docker_image:
- quay.io/condaforge/linux-anvil-x86_64:alma9
python_min:
- '3.9'

about.description:
hiPhive is a tool for efficiently extracting high-order force
constants from atomistic simulations, most commonly density
functional theory calculations. It has been implemented in the
form of a Python library, which allows it to be readily
integrated with many first-principles codes and analysis tools
accessible in Python.
about.summary: High-order force constants for the masses

about.description:
hiPhive is a tool for efficiently extracting high-order force
constants from atomistic simulations, most commonly density
functional theory calculations. It has been implemented in the
form of a Python library, which allows it to be readily
integrated with many first-principles codes and analysis tools
accessible in Python.
about.summary: High-order force constants for the masses

name: hiphive
raw_meta_yaml:
{% set name = "hiphive" %}
{% set version = "1.5" %}

package:
  name: {{ name|lower }}
  version: {{ version }}

source:
  url: https://pypi.org/packages/source/{{ name[0] }}/{{ name }}/{{ name }}-{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: a8162686265aed88cfa6ad2721f39629102525100879484530cb7c25269ac386

build:
  number: 0
  noarch: python
  script: {{ PYTHON }} -m pip install . -vv

requirements:
  host:
    - python {{ python_min }}
    - pip
    - setuptools
  run:
    - python >={{ python_min }}
    - ase
    - h5py
    - numba >=0.55
    - pandas
    - numpy >=1.18
    - scipy >=1.0.0
    - scikit-learn
    - spglib
    - sympy >=1.1
    - trainstation >=0.2

test:
  imports:
    - hiphive
  commands:
    - pip check
  requires:
    - pip
    - python {{ python_min }}

about:
  home: https://hiphive.materialsmodeling.org
  license: MIT
  license_family: MIT
  license_file: LICENSE
  summary: High-order force constants for the masses

  description: |
    hiPhive is a tool for efficiently extracting high-order force 
    constants from atomistic simulations, most commonly density 
    functional theory calculations. It has been implemented in the 
    form of a Python library, which allows it to be readily 
    integrated with many first-principles codes and analysis tools 
    accessible in Python.
  doc_url: https://hiphive.materialsmodeling.org
  dev_url: https://gitlab.com/materials-modeling/hiphive

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - jan-janssen
    - erhart1
